data.text:
Antonio Tabucchi was one of the most admired Italian writers of his generation, but he was something of an outsider among them. Not only was he rare in looking not to Anglophone literature but to the Mediterranean — and also to Portugal — for inspiration, but he was also unusual in being an early and open critic of Silvio Berlusconi. The two impulses combined in his best-known novel, Sostiene Pereira (Pereira Maintains, 1994). Set in 1938 in Tabucchi’s adopted home, Lisbon, it tells how a hitherto apolitical journalist comes to defy the repressive regime of Antonio Salazar through meeting a young radical whom he has commissioned to write obituaries.
